title: The New Kid in Robotics Club

chapters.text: Jake stood frozen at the doorway of the robotics club, clutching his backpack straps so tightly his knuckles turned white. Twenty pairs of eyes stared back at him. The room buzzed with the sounds of small motors and excited chatter that instantly died when he appeared. A tall girl with bright blue hair stepped forward. "You lost?" she asked, raising an eyebrow. Jake swallowed hard. This was his third school this year, and he'd promised himself he'd finally find his people. "I'm Jake. New kid. I like building things." The blue-haired girl exchanged glances with a boy wearing a NASA t-shirt. They seemed to communicate silently before she broke into a wide grin. "Perfect timing! Mia just moved away and we need someone for our competition team. I'm Zoe." She extended her hand, but Jake noticed the NASA boy frowning behind her.

Jake hesitantly shook her hand, feeling the NASA boy's disapproving stare burning into his back. "I'm Mia, club president," she said with a warm smile. "And that's Ethan behind me." The NASA boy—Ethan—gave a curt nod but didn't move from his workstation where a half-built robot sat surrounded by tools and orange wires that reminded Jake of carrots sticking out in all directions. Jake shifted his weight from one foot to the other, still gripping his backpack as Mia led him further into the classroom filled with computer parts, circuit boards, and various robot prototypes. The other club members gradually returned to their projects, the initial awkwardness fading as the room filled again with the sounds of clicking keyboards and quiet conversations. Jake took a deep breath, his shoulders relaxing slightly as Mia showed him to an empty desk.

Jake took a deep breath, his shoulders relaxing slightly as Mia showed him to an empty desk. The desk was cluttered with wires, circuit boards, and tiny screws that gleamed under the fluorescent lights. "This is where you'll work," Mia explained, brushing her dark hair behind her ear. "We're building battle robots this semester." Jake nodded, carefully setting his backpack down beside the chair. The room buzzed with activity as other students tinkered with metal parts and typed code into laptops. A boy with glasses at the next table looked up and waved, then returned to soldering something that sparked blue. Jake picked up a small motor from his desk, turning it over in his hands. The weight of it felt good, solid and real. Maybe this club wouldn't be so bad after all. He spotted a red APPLE sticker on the laptop Mia was opening for him, and smiled at the familiar logo.

Jake relaxed a little as Mia gestured for him to sit beside her. "You can use my laptop today," she said with a friendly smile. The robotics room buzzed with activity as students tinkered with metal parts and circuit boards. Jake carefully placed his backpack on the floor and slid into the empty chair. The laptop hummed to life, displaying a program with colorful blocks of code. Across the room, a tall boy demonstrated a robot that could pick up small objects. The robot's metal arm extended like a miniature SWORD, precisely grabbing a pencil from the table. Jake watched with wide eyes, forgetting his nervousness for a moment. "Pretty cool, right?" Mia whispered. "That's what we'll be building this semester." For the first time since entering the room, Jake felt a spark of excitement replace his fear. Maybe robotics club wouldn't be so bad after all.

Jake relaxed his grip on his backpack and took a deep breath. The robotics club room buzzed with activity as students worked on different projects. A tall girl with curly hair waved him over to an empty seat next to her workstation. "I'm Mia, team captain," she said with a friendly smile. "We're building underwater robots this semester." Jake noticed a small tank in the corner where a mechanical FISH-like robot bobbed in the water, its LED eyes glowing blue. The sight made him smile. Mr. Peterson, the club advisor, handed Jake a notebook and a basic robotics kit. "Welcome aboard," he said. "Everyone starts somewhere." As Jake sat down, Mia showed him the blueprint for their current project. The complicated design looked challenging, but the excitement in the room was contagious. Jake opened his notebook and picked up a pencil, ready to learn.

Jake opened his notebook and picked up a pencil, ready to learn. The robotics teacher, Mr. Wilson, smiled at him and continued explaining how to program the small robots on the table. Jake wrote down every important detail, glancing occasionally at the digital clock on the wall that showed they still had forty minutes left in the meeting. The other students were already working in groups, connecting wires and typing code into laptops. A girl with curly hair and glasses waved Jake over to her table where a half-built robot sat surrounded by tools and spare parts. Jake hesitated for a moment, then walked over with his notebook, feeling less nervous than when he first arrived. The robot on the table beeped and moved its mechanical arm as if saying hello, making Jake smile for the first time since entering the robotics club.

The robot's friendly gesture broke the tension in the room, and a girl with curly hair stepped forward. "I'm Mia, club president. That's Sparky—he likes new people." Jake relaxed his grip on his backpack and moved closer to examine Sparky's design. The other students gathered around, pointing out different features they had built together. By the end of the meeting, Jake had helped program Sparky to wave and spin in circles when someone said "hello." As weeks passed, Jake became an essential part of the team, using his talent for coding to improve their robots. When the regional competition arrived, it was Jake's programming that helped their robot navigate the obstacle course perfectly. Standing with his teammates as they held the first-place trophy, Jake realized he had found more than just a club—he had found where he belonged.
